FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
As this is a new stationary source, no accident has occurred meeting the criteria that requires reporting under the EPA RMP program.  
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Ormat staff are not First Responders. Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency. Ormat coordinates with local fire department and first responders.
An emergency action plan is in place that meets the requirements of EPA RMP, OSHA PSM and Nevada CAPP.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Ormat conducted a PHA study to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety were listed as recommendations in the PHA Report and were implemented prior to startup.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
One worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario has been defined and modeled for the process. Results are included with this submittal. 
RISK CONSIDERATIONS
Although the use of a motive fluid has inherent potential risks, and worst-case and alternative case release scenarios cannot reach public receptors.  However, Ormat recognizes the potential risks to plant personnel and has structured its process design and safety programs to make these types of release events improbable.  
Design safeguards include the following: 
•	Automatic Shutdown is initiated when select process variable ranges are exceeded.
o	Stop brine flow, initiating unit depressurization
o	Close process isolation valves, removing motive fluid feed to turbines to stop turbine rotation
o	Stop process feed pumps
o	Disconnect electrical grid breakers 
•	Operator-initiated Shutdown can be activated from the control room and from various locations around the stationary source to prompt the same actions initiated by an automatic shutdown. 
•	Pressure Relief System is designed to prevent system overpressure due to process upsets such as blocked flow or accidents resulting in equipment exposure to fire.
•	Physical Separation of the process from potential public receptors.
Safety programs are defined by the Accidental Release Prevention Program described below.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Although the North Valley process qualifies for an EPA-RMP Program level 1, an accidental release prevention program has been developed to meet the requirements of OSHA PSM and Nevada CAPP.  As part of the implementation of the accidental release prevention program, program elements are documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of the motive fluid.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedure

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
Ormat has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan at its North Valley process to address the requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program (EPA RMP - 40CFR68), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM - 29CFR1910.119) and the State of Nevada Chemical Accident Prevention Program (Nevada CAPP - NAC 459.952 - 95528).  Ormat is highly diligent in handling the process of motive fluid and Isopentane and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Ormat staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards while effectively and safely using the motive fluid for geothermal power production.
Ormat has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the motive fluid system. Ormats policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of motive fluid.
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
Ormats geothermal power production facility is fueled by geothermal brine from a reservoir located in the San Emidio Valley. The facility is located north of Reno, Nevada in an area that is generally uninhabited. The facility uses the process motive fluid as a working fluid in a binary Rankine cycle process for power production. There is one process in the stationary source.  The process is new with commissioning occurring in 1Q23.
The regulated substance managed at the stationary source is the previously mentioned motive fluid, Isopentane. The motive fluid circulates in a closed-loop power cycle, traveling through accumulators, pumps, heat exchangers, turbines, and condensers to produce electricity with turbine-driven generators.
